So said  Mike Clark  on  1/25/2003 --------------------

>J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
>
>>Wonderfully. For those of you with taste, please prod me to get off
my
>>ass and write my upcoming article, "Unit Testing within Frameworks",
>>which covers strategies for frameworks including EJB, Servlet,
Turbine,
>>Struts and anything else people can suggest to me.
>
>Yes, please write that article already.  :-)

I'm already a few hundred words in. I am in a race with my wife to
complete an article by Wednesday night, when I return home from lovely
Lexington MA. I figure this is a good way to prod her into writing one
of the many books she's threatened to write in the past few years.

>An alternative title comes to mind:
>
>    "How to decouple your code from their framework"

This is an excellent title. I just may use it.

>People tell me that books and articles with "testing" in the title
don't 
>sell as well as they'd like.  It's a shame really, and I hope to help 
>change that mentality.  One of my tactics in doing so, as you well
know, 
>is to convince readers that testing is also a design activity.  As
such, 
>I should be able to change any phrase about testing into a phrase
about 
>design.  It's something I've been practicing, and this title is one 
>attempt.     

I have noticed that, even in the words I've written so far, that I
often write, "... use this stuff to write the test that drives the
design you need to complete your task." A bit wordy, but repeated often
enough, it may hammer home the very point you're making.

>Now, please write that article!  :-)

I wrote for 30 minutes on the plane and about an hour when I got here.
See: I'm good!
